name: direction table
structure: Produces entries for different types of genres and worlds. The 'common' and 'rare' tables are generic and should be compatible with almost any world. To retain compatibility with most settings, the  non-generic tables should be called only from other tables by specifying their name directly.
note: The Greek subtables contains Greek letters, Unicode characters required.

tables.name: direction
tables.explanation: Direction types by scarcity.

tables.name: common
tables.explanation: Common compass direction types.

tables.name: rare
tables.explanation: Rare compass direction systems.
tables.note: A table name cannot begin with a number!

tables.name: sixteen winds
tables.explanation: Principal winds and the half-winds.

tables.name: thirtytwo winds
tables.explanation: Principal winds, half-winds and quarter winds.

tables.name: mythological
tables.explanation: Direction systems from history.

tables.name: Charlemagne
tables.explanation: Frankish 12 winds as invented by Charlemagne.

tables.name: Mediterranean
tables.explanation: Medieval mariner's 8 winds in the Mediterranean Sea.

tables.name: rare mythological
tables.explanation: Rare direction systems from history.

tables.name: Biblical
tables.explanation: The ancient Greek directional systems.

tables.name: Greek
tables.explanation: The ancient Greek directional systems.

tables.name: Homer
tables.explanation: The ancient 4 Greek compass winds, as used by Homer.

tables.name: Aristotle
tables.explanation: The ancient 10 Greek compass winds, as used by Aristotle.

tables.name: Timosthenes
tables.explanation: The ancient Greco-Roman 12 classical compass winds, as used by Timosthenes of Rhodes.

tables.name: Roman
tables.explanation: The ancient Roman directional systems.

tables.name: Vitruvius
tables.explanation: The ancient Roman 24 compass winds, as used by Vitruvius.

tables.name: Seneca
tables.explanation: The ancient Roman 12 compass winds, as used by Seneca.

tables.name: Pliny
tables.explanation: The ancient Roman 8 compass winds, as used by Pliny the Elder.

tables.name: Aulus Gellius
tables.explanation: The ancient Roman 8 compass winds, as used by Aulus Gellius.

tables.name: fantasy
tables.explanation: Direction systems for fantasy worlds.
entries: hubwards (towards the center of the world)
turnwise (following the rotation of the world)
rimwards (towards the edge of the world)
widdershins (against the rotation of the world)

tables.name: modern
tables.explanation: Direction systems for modern worlds.

tables.name: futuristic
tables.explanation: Direction systems for science fiction worlds.
entries: {common} in the {coordinate system} celestial coordinate system

tables.name: coordinate system
tables.explanation: Common direction systems for science fiction worlds.

tables.name: rare futuristic
tables.explanation: Rare direction systems for science fiction worlds.
entries: {common} in the {rare coordinate system} coordinate system

tables.name: rare coordinate system
tables.explanation: Rare direction systems for science fiction worlds.
entries: galactic (based on the plane of the local galaxy)
supergalactic (based on the plane of the local galaxy group)
